comment.author: 93957686@N00
comment._content: Checking Newell Bent's American Polo (published by Macmillan in 1929) reveals that there was a series of international matches between American and British teams around this time. There was no such match in 1910, but there were matches in 1909 and 1911 (among other years). Comparing this photo to photos in the book shows similar uniforms (dark shirt, pith-type helmet with dark band around it) for the British teams; for example there's a photo of the 1914 British team on page 189. So I tentatively suggest that this might be a photo of one of the British international polo teams of that era.

comment.author: 93957686@N00
comment._content: Thanks, budderflyman. I based 1910 on the date given in the stats under the copyright notice. It turns out that there was international polo played in 1910 after all; there are lots of articles in the New York Times covering it. Matches (though not a match for the championship; that match was scheduled but then cancelled due to injury to one of the British riders) were played at Georgian Court in Lakewood, NJ, and at the Meadow Brook Hunt Club on Long Island, NY. Meadow Brook was also a venue for matches later on in the decade.

comment.author: 93957686@N00
comment._content: b - I was thinking that it was Meadow Brook, too, but looking through the 1910 NY Times polo articles shows that games involving the Brits took place at Georgian Court at Lakewood, NJ, (April) and Wildfield Farm at Narragansett Pier, RI (August). Although Meadow Brook polo players were involved in some of these matches, it appears no matches took place at Meadow Brook that year. I want to see if I can place that building in either NJ or RI, but haven't found anything yet.
